Authors:
Doaa Abdel Mohsen Komeil, Ahmed Farag El Bebany, Mohamed
Yasser Abdalla, Ayman Basyony Basyony
Title:
Application of molecular marker for agrobiodiversity of date
palm cultivars resistance to Fusarium wilt
Keywords:
date palm, molecular marker, Fusarium wilt,
pathogenicity.
Abstract:
Date palm (Phoenix dactylifera L.) is an economically
important food crop in Egypt, contributing in the preservation of the
arid ecosystem threatened by desertification. In the current study, an
isolate of Fusarium oxysporum was isolated from an infected orchard from
Aswan (Upper Egypt). Pathogenicity testing of the isolate on ten date
palm varieties from various origins showed that all of them were
susceptible to Fusarium oxysporum Aswan but with various degrees.
Cultivars Sakooty and Barhi were the most susceptible, Siwae, Deglet
Noor and Sagae were moderately resistant. Succary cultivar was the least
susceptible one. A mitochondrial molecular marker to test date palm
germplasms for resistance/ susceptibility to the Bayoud disease was
applied in using PCR based on the two primers oli1 and oli2. The results
revealed that all germplasms of Egyptian cultivars had susceptibility
marker. However, Sakooty and Bartmoda were highly susceptible to
Fusarium oxysporum Aswan, whereas Siwa showed moderate resistance.
Cultivar Deglet Noor whether from Algeria or from Tunisia and Succary
from Saudi Arabia had resistance marker, Succary cultivar was actually
the most resistant cultivar to infection with Fusarium oxysporum.
